definitions.definition: rails (= metal bars) that a train moves along

examples.text: **railway/railroad tracks**
We crossed the rail/train track.
India has thousands of miles of track.
Many branch lines were closed, and the tracks lifted.

definitions.definition: a track with a number at a train station that a train arrives at or leaves from

examples.text: The train for Chicago is on track 9.

definitions.definition: a piece of ground with a special surface for people, cars, etc. to have races or to drive on

examples.text: a **race track**
a Formula One Grand Prix track *(= for motor racing)*
a running track
The company already operates a greyhound track.
Yesterday I had track practice.
A few planes were parked on the perimeter track of the airfield.
A sign marks where the cycle track (= a special route for cyclists) ends.
a single track road (= wide enough for only one vehicle) with passing places

definitions.definition: the sport of running on a track

examples.text: He loves sports and participates in track and basketball.

definitions.definition: a rough path or road, usually one that has not been built but that has been made by people walking there

examples.text: a muddy track through the forest
a dirt track
We were bumping along the rough track that led to the lake.
They had to drive up a dirt track.
The path joins a farm track near a barn.
The green hills were criss-crossed with sheep tracks.
An ancient track crosses the moors.
A forest track leads up to the waterfall.
A cart track led to the farm.
When the track forks, take the left fork.

definitions.definition: marks left by a person, an animal or a moving vehicle

examples.text: We followed the bear's tracks in the snow.
Leading away into the bushes were fresh rabbit tracks.
tyre tracks
The beach is criss-crossed with animal tracks.

definitions.definition: the path or direction that somebody/something is moving in

examples.text: He switched tracks and went back to college.
Police are on the track of *(= searching for)* the thieves.
Film comedy developed along a similar track to film drama.
She decided to change her career track.
The ship was on a southerly track.
a twin track approach to crime
Students pursue one of three tracks: professional writing, film/​television/​video or new media.
She felt the excitement of a journalist on the track of a good story.

definitions.definition: a recording of one song or piece of music

examples.text: a track from their latest album
The album kicks off with the **title track** *(= a song with the same name as the album)*.
The opening track is sweet and sentimental.
There are thirteen tracks on the album.
This song is easily the disc's standout track.
She had already cut a couple of tracks as lead singer with her own group.

definitions.definition: part of a computer disk or tape that music or information can be recorded on

examples.text: a sixteen track recording studio
She sang on the backing track.

definitions.definition: the soundtrack of a film or video

examples.text: The film is available with French and Spanish audio tracks.
There is a commentary track by the director.

definitions.definition: a long, thin, straight piece of metal, wood or plastic that a curtain hangs from and moves along
a continuous belt of metal plates around the wheels of a large vehicle such as a bulldozer that allows it to move over the ground
going in the right direction again after a mistake, failure, etc.

examples.text: I tried to get my life back on track after my divorce.

definitions.definition: to be doing the right thing in order to achieve a particular result

examples.text: Curtis is on track for the gold medal.

definitions.definition: to try and hide what you have done, because you do not want other people to find out about it

examples.text: He had attempted to cover his tracks by wiping the hard disk on his computer.

definitions.definition: from or living in a poor area or part of town
close to catching or finding the person or thing that you have been running after or searching for
to have/not have information about what is happening or where somebody/something is

examples.text: Bank statements help you keep track of where your money is going.
I lost all track of time *(= forgot what time it was)*.

definitions.definition: to leave a place, especially to go home

examples.text: It’s getting late—I’d better make tracks.

definitions.definition: far away from other people, houses, etc.

examples.text: They live miles off the beaten track.

definitions.definition: thinking or behaving in the right/wrong way

examples.text: We haven’t found a cure yet—but we are on the right track.
The new manager successfully got the team back onto the right track.
The police were on the wrong track when they treated the case as a revenge killing.

definitions.definition: to suddenly make somebody stop by frightening or surprising them; to suddenly stop because something has frightened or surprised you

examples.text: The question stopped Alice in her tracks.
Suddenly he stopped dead in his tracks: what was he doing?
The disease was stopped in its tracks by immunization programmes.

wordOrigin: late 15th cent. (in the sense ‘trail, marks left behind’): the noun from Old French trac, perhaps from Low German or Dutch trek ‘draught, drawing’; the verb (current senses dating from the mid 16th cent.) from French traquer or directly from the noun.
